perturbation.original_text: The undersigned acknowledge that each shall be responsible for the timely filing of any amendments, and for the completeness and accuracy of the information concerning the undersigned or contained herein and therein, but shall not be responsible for the completeness and accuracy of the information concerning the others.
perturbation.changed_text: The undersigned acknowledge that each shall be responsible for filing initial statements only. No party shall be responsible for the timely filing of any amendments, or for the completeness and accuracy of any information, regardless of who it concerns.
perturbation.explanation: This change removes the responsibility for timely filing of amendments and accuracy of information, contradicting SEC regulations that require ongoing and accurate disclosures. All parties are responsible for keeping the information up to date, and this abrogation of duty creates a legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Exchange Act of 1934, Rule 13d-1(k)(1) and related SEC regulations regarding ongoing disclosure obligations.

perturbation.original_text: In accordance with Rule 13d-1(k)(1) promulgated under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, the undersigned hereby agree to the joint filing with each of the Reporting Persons (as such term is defined in the Schedule 13D referred to below) on behalf of each of them of a statement on Schedule 13D (including amendments thereto and statements on Schedule 13G) with respect to the Common Stock, par value $0.01 per share of Macy's, Inc., a corporation organized under the laws of the State of Delaware, and that this agreement may be included as an exhibit to such joint filing.
perturbation.changed_text: Notwithstanding Rule 13d-1(k)(1) promulgated under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, the undersigned hereby agree to individual filings only. No joint filings will be made under any circumstances.
perturbation.explanation: This explicitly contradicts Rule 13d-1(k)(1) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, which permits and regulates joint filings. Forcing individual filings when the parties are acting as a group circumvents the intended disclosure requirements and creates a legal contradiction.
